ISO/IEC DIS 42006 A Guide to Implementation EU AI Act April 2025

This document excerpt presents a guide to the implementation of ISO/IEC DIS 42006, a standard related to AI governance. It‚Äôs produced by AI & Partners, a company dedicated to defending digital rights of users at risk globally through a multifaceted approach including technical support, policy engagement, advocacy, and regulatory interventions. The core mission is to ensure fundamental rights are upheld within the context of artificial intelligence. The guide specifically addresses the EU AI Act and its connection to the ISO/IEC standard. It outlines key questions being explored regarding the standard, including its purpose and the principles underpinning AIMS (Artificial Intelligence Management Systems) certification. The document highlights AI & Partners' involvement in industry groups like AI Commons, demonstrating their commitment to shaping the future of AI governance. The excerpt details the contributions of several individuals from AI & Partners ‚Äì Sean Musch, Michael Borrelli, Charles Kerrigan, Filiz Demerci, Vibhav Mithal, Anand and Anand Leonardo Freixas, Xiaochen Zhang, and Helen Yu ‚Äì who are involved in the creation and dissemination of this guide. The publication is presented as an AI & Partners publication, and contact information for Michael Borrelli, the Director, is provided. The document serves as an introductory overview, setting the stage for a more detailed exploration of the ISO/IEC 42006 standard and its implications for AI management and governance. It emphasizes a proactive stance in safeguarding user rights within the evolving landscape of artificial intelligence. The excerpt‚Äôs focus on the EU AI Act underscores the importance of aligning AI development and deployment with regulatory frameworks.

Key Concepts:

  • Guidance on implementing ISO/IEC DIS 42006
  • Principles for AIMS certification
  • Advocacy for digital rights in the age of AI
  • Stage 2 testing through interviews, system inspections, and sample checks to validate ISO 42001 compliance.
  • Major nonconformities requiring closure before certificate issuance.
  • Annual surveillance audits and full re-certification for AIMS effectiveness and updates.
  • Pre-audit agreements defining safeguards for sensitive information (e.g., source code, raw data).
  • Contractual and technical measures to protect intellectual property during audits.
  • Sector-specific extensions to ISO/IEC 42001 Annex A controls for regulated industries.
  • A comprehensive framework for conducting AIMS certifications.
